metadata.case_number: Criminal Appeal No. of 2008 (Special Leave Petition (Criminal) No. 5265 of 2007)

facts.text: Sanjay Pal got financed a Maruti Van bearing No. DL-1CB-4065 from Shri Manoj Kumar Sharma - Vijay Lakshmi Finance Investment Company for Rs. 30,000/- and paid Rs. 3954/- as first installment.

Man Mohan Sharma informed Sanjay Pal that the finance was fabricated, took over financing under Real Auto Deals, received old R.C., gave new R.C., received monthly installments in cash without proper receipts or letterhead, encashed cheques in different names.
Sanjay Pal stopped cheque payments upon noticing fraud, sent notice to pay in name of Real Auto Deals.
On 27.12.1995, Man Mohan Sharma along with unknown person took the Maruti Van without consent using a paper stamped by police.
Vijay Lakshmi Finance, Real Auto Deals and Man Mohan Sharma sold the vehicle using forged signatures and fraud.
FIR No.50/1997 dated 31.01.1997 registered at P.S. Vivek Vihar, East Delhi under Sections 420/468/471/34/120-B IPC based on statement of Sanjay Pal.
Charges framed against appellant Manoj Sharma and co-accused Man Mohan Sharma.
Appellant filed writ petition in Delhi High Court to quash FIR on ground of compromise between complainant and accused.
Complainant filed affidavit in writ petition withdrawing allegations against both petitioners, stating settlement where Rs.45,000/- paid to Manoj Sharma and Rs.45,000/- to Man Mohan Sharma.
Delhi High Court rejected writ petition on 17.08.2007.

legal_issues.text: Whether a First Information Report under Sections 420/468/471/34/120-B IPC can be quashed under Section 482 CrPC or Article 226 of the Constitution when the accused and the complainant have compromised and settled the matter between themselves.

petitioner_arguments.text: Strongly relied on B.S. Joshi v. State of Haryana to argue that High Court has power under Section 482 CrPC or Article 226 to quash FIR even for non-compoundable offences where parties have settled, to prevent abuse of process and secure ends of justice.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: B.S. Joshi v. State of Haryana (2003) 4 SCC 675; Section 482 CrPC; Article 226

respondent_arguments.text: Decision in B.S. Joshi requires reconsideration as offences are non-compoundable under Section 320 CrPC; High Court cannot quash non-compoundable offences via Section 482 or Article 226, departing from earlier precedents.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 320 CrPC; Inspector of Police CBI v. Rajagopal (2002) 9 SCC 533; K.G. Prem Shankar v. Inspector of Police JT 2002(7) SC 30; Textile Labour Association v. Official Liquidator JT 2004 Suppl.1 SC 1

court_reasoning.text: Power under Section 482 CrPC or Article 226 not circumscribed by Section 320 CrPC; depends on facts to prevent abuse of process or secure ends of justice; followed B.S. Joshi; dispute private in nature, complainant not pursuing, continuing proceedings futile.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court should have exercised jurisdiction pragmatically given settlement.

court_reasoning.text: Section 482 has non-obstante clause overriding Section 320 in rare cases; B.S. Joshi provides creative solution for non-compoundable offences like 498A where conviction unlikely post-settlement; needs larger bench for guidelines on when to quash non-compoundable cases.
court_reasoning.key_observation: In cases akin to civil nature, proceedings can be quashed on amicable settlement even if non-compoundable.

holdings.text: High Court has power under Section 482 CrPC or Article 226 to quash criminal proceedings/FIR/complaint even if offences non-compoundable, based on facts to prevent abuse of process or secure ends of justice.

precedents_cited.case_name: B.S. Joshi v. State of Haryana
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court can quash non-compoundable proceedings under S.482 CrPC if ends of justice require, e.g., post-compromise in 498A cases.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pepsi Foods Ltd. v. Special Judicial Magistrate
precedents_cited.relevance: No rigid formula for exercising S.482 jurisdiction; depends on facts to prevent abuse or secure justice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Inspector of Police CBI v. Rajagopal
precedents_cited.relevance: Respondent argued departure from this in B.S. Joshi.

precedents_cited.case_name: K.G. Prem Shankar v. Inspector of Police
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by respondent against quashing non-compoundable offences.

precedents_cited.case_name: Textile Labour Association v. Official Liquidator

precedents_cited.relevance: Followed B.S. Joshi in quashing proceedings post-compromise.

precedents_cited.case_name: Madhu Limaye v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: S.482 power not to be exercised against express bar, but distinguished in context.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences alleged in FIR; 420 compoundable with permission, others non-compoundable.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973
statutes_cited.relevance: S.482 allows quashing to secure ends of justice overriding S.320 non-compoundability; S.320 lists compoundable offences.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court's writ jurisdiction to quash FIR/proceedings.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order dated 17.08.2007 set aside; criminal proceedings in FIR No.50/1997 dated 31.01.1997 P.S. Vivek Vihar quashed before Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Karkardooma Courts, Delhi.
outcome.relief_granted: Quashing of FIR and criminal proceedings

key_quotes.text: the power of the High Court under Section 482 of the Code to quash Criminal proceedings or FIR or complaint were not circumscribed by Section 320 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding affirming B.S. Joshi on inherent powers overriding compoundability.

key_quotes.text: continuing with the criminal proceedings would be an exercise in futility.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason for quashing given private settlement and complainant withdrawal.

key_quotes.text: Section 482 is a non obstante clause, and gives it overriding effect over other provisions in the Cr.P.C.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why S.482 can override S.320 in rare cases.
